newsitem.title: USA: Netscape agrees to support components.
newsitem.headline: Netscape agrees to support components.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp said it adopted Sun Microsystems Inc's JavaBeans component model and to work on enhancing an industry component effort known as CORBA.

Netscape said in a news release before its third developers conference in San Jose that JavaBeans - which can be used to snap together prebuilt blocks of software code - will be the platform-independent component model for its Netscape ONE platform.
Netscape said it will work with Sun, International Business Machines Corp and database company Oracle Corp to find ways to bring JavaBeans closer to the CORBA component standard.
The companies began their colllaboration in March and last week submitted a joint position paper to the Object Management Group, a standards body, Netscape said.

More than 65 companies announced support for JavaBeans, with more than 50 of these planning to deliver more than 90 components for inclusion in a directory of the prebuilt software blocks to be hosted on Netscape's Internet site for developers.
The standard is considered in the industry to rival Microsoft Corp's component model known as DCOM.

The software industry has long been aiming to design products that can reuse software by enabling such blocks of pre-written software to be assembled by plugging them in to programs as they are written.
